defs.docs: Hound, a wav encoding and decoding library.

attributes.value: / Hound, a wav encoding and decoding library.
/ Examples
/ The following example renders a 440 Hz sine wave, and stores it as as a
/ mono wav file with a sample rate of 44.1 kHz and 16 bits per sample.
/ use std::f32::consts::PI;
/ use std::i16;
/ use hound;
/ let spec = hound::WavSpec {
/     channels: 1,
/     sample_rate: 44100,
/     bits_per_sample: 16,
/     sample_format: hound::SampleFormat::Int,
/ let mut writer = hound::WavWriter::create("sine.wav", spec).unwrap();
/     let sample = (t * 440.0 * 2.0 * PI).sin();
/     let amplitude = i16::MAX as f32;
/     writer.write_sample((sample * amplitude) as i16).unwrap();
/ writer.finalize().unwrap();
/ The following example computes the root mean square (RMS) of an audio file
/ with at most 16 bits per sample.
/ use hound;
/ let mut reader = hound::WavReader::open("testsamples/pop.wav").unwrap();
/ let sqr_sum = reader.samples::<i16>()
/                     .fold(0.0, |sqr_sum, s| {
/     let sample = s.unwrap() as f64;
/     sqr_sum + sample * sample
/ println!("RMS is {}", (sqr_sum / reader.len() as f64).sqrt());
warn(missing_docs)

defs.name: WavReader
defs.docs: A reader that reads the WAVE format from the underlying reader.

attributes.value: / A reader that reads the WAVE format from the underlying reader.
/ A `WavReader` is a streaming reader. It reads data from the underlying
/ reader on demand, and it reads no more than strictly necessary. No internal
/ buffering is performed on the underlying reader, but this can easily be
/ added by wrapping the reader in an `io::BufReader`. The `open` constructor
/ takes care of this for you.

defs.name: WavSamples
defs.docs: An iterator that yields samples of type `S` read from a `WavReader`.

attributes.value: / An iterator that yields samples of type `S` read from a `WavReader`.
/ The type `S` must have at least as many bits as the bits per sample of the
/ file, otherwise every iteration will return an error.

defs.name: WavIntoSamples
defs.docs: An iterator that yields samples of type `S` read from a `WavReader`.

attributes.value: / An iterator that yields samples of type `S` read from a `WavReader`.
/ The type `S` must have at least as many bits as the bits per sample of the
/ file, otherwise every iteration will return an error.

defs.name: read_wave_header
defs.value: pub fn read_wave_header<R: io::Read>(&mut R) -> Result<u64>
defs.docs: Reads the RIFF WAVE header, returns the supposed file size.

attributes.value: / Reads the RIFF WAVE header, returns the supposed file size.
/ This function can be used to quickly check if the file could be a wav file
/ by reading 12 bytes of the header. If an `Ok` is returned, the file is
/ likely a wav file. If an `Err` is returned, it is definitely not a wav
/ file.
/ The returned file size cannot be larger than 2<sup>32</sup> + 7 bytes.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Attempts to create a reader that reads the WAVE format.

attributes.value: / Attempts to create a reader that reads the WAVE format.
/ The header is read immediately. Reading the data will be done on
/ demand.

defs.name: spec
defs.docs: Returns information about the WAVE file.

attributes.value: / Returns information about the WAVE file.

defs.name: samples
defs.value: pub fn samples<'wr, S: Sample>(&'wr mut Self) -> WavSamples
defs.docs: Returns an iterator over all samples.

attributes.value: / Returns an iterator over all samples.
/ The channel data is is interleaved. The iterator is streaming. That is,
/ if you call this method once, read a few samples, and call this method
/ again, the second iterator will not start again from the beginning of
/ the file, it will continue where the first iterator stopped.
/ The type `S` must have at least `spec().bits_per_sample` bits,
/ otherwise every iteration will return an error. All bit depths up to
/ 32 bits per sample can be decoded into an `i32`, but if you know
/ beforehand that you will be reading a file with 16 bits per sample, you
/ can save memory by decoding into an `i16`.
/ The type of `S` (int or float) must match `spec().sample_format`,
/ otherwise every iteration will return an error.

defs.name: into_samples
defs.value: pub fn into_samples<S: Sample>(Self) -> WavIntoSamples<R, S>
defs.docs: Same as `samples`, but takes ownership of the `WavReader`.

attributes.value: / Same as `samples`, but takes ownership of the `WavReader`.
/ See `samples()` for more info.

defs.name: duration
defs.docs: Returns the duration of the file in samples.

attributes.value: / Returns the duration of the file in samples.
/ The duration is independent of the number of channels. It is expressed
/ in units of samples. The duration in seconds can be obtained by
/ dividing this number by the sample rate. The duration is independent of
/ how many samples have been read already.

defs.name: len
defs.docs: Returns the number of values that the sample iterator will yield.

attributes.value: / Returns the number of values that the sample iterator will yield.
/ The length of the file is its duration (in samples) times the number of
/ channels. The length is independent of how many samples have been read
/ already. To get the number of samples left, use `len()` on the
/ `samples()` iterator.

defs.name: into_inner
defs.docs: Destroys the `WavReader` and returns the underlying reader.

attributes.value: / Destroys the `WavReader` and returns the underlying reader.

defs.name: seek
defs.value: pub fn seek(&mut Self, u32) -> io::Result<()> where R: io::Seek
defs.docs: Seek to the given time within the file.

attributes.value: / Seek to the given time within the file.
/ The given time is measured in number of samples (independent of the
/ number of channels) since the beginning of the audio data. To seek to
/ a particular time in seconds, multiply the number of seconds with
/ `WavSpec::sample_rate`. The given time should not exceed the duration of
/ the file (returned by `duration()`). The behavior when seeking beyond
/ `duration()` depends on the reader's `Seek` implementation.
/ This method requires that the inner reader `R` implements `Seek`.

defs.name: open
defs.docs: Attempts to create a reader that reads from the specified file.

attributes.value: / Attempts to create a reader that reads from the specified file.
/ This is a convenience constructor that opens a `File`, wraps it in a
/ `BufReader` and then constructs a `WavReader` from it.

defs.name: WavWriter
defs.docs: A writer that accepts samples and writes the WAVE format.

attributes.value: / A writer that accepts samples and writes the WAVE format.
/ The writer needs a `WavSpec` that describes the audio properties. Then
/ samples can be written with `write_sample`. Channel data is interleaved.
/ The number of samples written must be a multiple of the number of channels.
/ After all samples have been written, the file must be finalized. This can
/ be done by calling `finalize`. If `finalize` is not called, the file will
/ be finalized upon drop. However, finalization may fail, and without calling
/ `finalize`, such a failure cannot be observed.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a writer that writes the WAVE format to the underlying writer.

attributes.value: / Creates a writer that writes the WAVE format to the underlying writer.
/ The underlying writer is assumed to be at offset 0. `WavWriter` employs
/ *no* buffering internally. It is recommended to wrap the writer in a
/ `BufWriter` to avoid too many `write` calls. The `create()` constructor
/ does this automatically.
/ This writes parts of the header immediately, hence a `Result` is
/ returned.

defs.name: write_sample
defs.value: pub fn write_sample<S: Sample>(&mut Self, S) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Writes a single sample for one channel.

attributes.value: / Writes a single sample for one channel.
/ WAVE interleaves channel data, so the channel that this writes the
/ sample to depends on previous writes. This will return an error if the
/ sample does not fit in the number of bits specified in the `WavSpec`.
inline

defs.name: get_i16_writer
defs.value: pub fn get_i16_writer<'s>(&'s mut Self, u32) -> SampleWriter16
defs.docs: Create an efficient writer that writes 16-bit integer samples only.

attributes.value: / Create an efficient writer that writes 16-bit integer samples only.
/ When it is known what the kind of samples will be, many dynamic checks
/ can be omitted. Furthermore, this writer employs buffering internally,
/ which allows omitting return value checks except on flush. The internal
/ buffer will be sized such that exactly `num_samples` samples can be
/ written to it, and the buffer is recycled across calls to
/ `get_i16_writer()` if the previous buffer was sufficiently large.
/ # Panics
/ Panics if the spec does not match a 16 bits per sample integer format.
/ Attempting to write more than `num_samples` samples to the writer will
/ panic too.

defs.name: flush
defs.docs: Updates the WAVE header and flushes the underlying writer.

attributes.value: / Updates the WAVE header and flushes the underlying writer.
/ Flush writes the WAVE header to the underlying writer to make the
/ written bytes a valid wav file, and then flushes the writer. It is still
/ possible to write more samples after flushing.
/ Flush can be used for checkpointing. Even if after the flush there is
/ an IO error or the writing process dies, the file can still be read by a
/ compliant decoder up to the last flush.
/ Note that if the number of samples written is not a multiple of the
/ channel count, the intermediate wav file will not be valid. In that case
/ `flush()` will still flush the data and write the (invalid) wav file,
/ but `Error::UnfinishedSample` will be returned afterwards.
/ It is not necessary to call `finalize()` directly after `flush()`, if no
/ samples have been written after flushing.

defs.name: finalize
defs.docs: Updates the WAVE header (which requires knowing all samples).

attributes.value: / Updates the WAVE header (which requires knowing all samples).
/ This method must be called after all samples have been written. If it
/ is not called, the destructor will finalize the file, but any errors
/ that occur in the process cannot be observed in that manner.

defs.name: spec
defs.docs: Returns information about the WAVE file being written.

attributes.value: / Returns information about the WAVE file being written.
/ This is the same spec that was passed to `WavWriter::new()`. For a
/ writer constructed with `WavWriter::new_append()` or
/ `WavWriter::append()`, this method returns the spec of the file being
/ appended to.

defs.name: duration
defs.docs: Returns the duration of the file written so far, in samples.

attributes.value: / Returns the duration of the file written so far, in samples.
/ The duration is independent of the number of channels. It is expressed
/ in units of samples. The duration in seconds can be obtained by
/ dividing this number by the sample rate.

defs.name: len
defs.docs: Returns the number of samples in the file written so far.

attributes.value: / Returns the number of samples in the file written so far.
/ The length of the file is its duration (in samples) times the number of
/ channels.

defs.name: create
defs.docs: Creates a writer that writes the WAVE format to a file.

attributes.value: / Creates a writer that writes the WAVE format to a file.
/ This is a convenience constructor that creates the file, wraps it in a
/ `BufWriter`, and then constructs a `WavWriter` from it. The file will
/ be overwritten if it exists.

defs.name: append
defs.docs: Creates a writer that appends samples to an existing file.

attributes.value: / Creates a writer that appends samples to an existing file.
/ This is a convenience constructor that opens the file in append mode,
/ reads its header using a buffered reader, and then constructs an
/ appending `WavWriter` that writes to the file using a `BufWriter`.
/ See `WavWriter::new_append()` for more details about append behavior.

defs.name: new_append
defs.docs: Creates a writer that appends samples to an existing file stream.

attributes.value: / Creates a writer that appends samples to an existing file stream.
/ This first reads the existing header to obtain the spec, then seeks to
/ the end of the writer. The writer then appends new samples to the end of
/ the stream.
/ The underlying writer is assumed to be at offset 0.
/ If the existing file includes a fact chunk, it will not be updated after
/ appending, and hence become outdated. For files produced by Hound this
/ is not an issue, because Hound never writes a fact chunk. For all the
/ formats that Hound can write, the fact chunk is redundant.

defs.name: SampleWriter16
defs.docs: A writer that specifically only writes integer samples of 16 bits per sample.

attributes.value: / A writer that specifically only writes integer samples of 16 bits per sample.
/ The writer buffers written samples internally so they can be written in a
/ single batch later on. This has two advantages when performance is
/ important:
/  * There is no need for error handling during writing, only on flush. This
/    eliminates a lot of branches.
/  * The buffer can be written once, which reduces the overhead of the write
/    call. Because writing to an `io::BufWriter` is implemented with a
/    `memcpy` (even for single bytes), there is a large overhead to writing
/    small amounts of data such as a 16-bit sample. By writing large blocks
/    (or by not using `BufWriter`) this overhead can be avoided.
/ A `SampleWriter16` can be obtained by calling [`WavWriter::get_i16_writer`](
/ struct.WavWriter.html#method.get_i16_writer).

defs.name: write_sample
defs.value: pub fn write_sample<S: Sample>(&mut Self, S)
defs.docs: Writes a single sample for one channel.

attributes.value: / Writes a single sample for one channel.
/ WAVE interleaves channel data, so the channel that this writes the
/ sample to depends on previous writes.
/ Unlike `WavWriter::write_sample()`, no range check is performed. Only
/ the least significant 16 bits are considered, everything else is
/ discarded.  Apart from that check, this method is more efficient than
/ `WavWriter::write_sample()`, because it can avoid dispatching on the
/ number of bits. That was done already when the `SampleWriter16` was
/ constructed.
/ Note that nothing is actually written until `flush()` is called.
inline(always)

defs.name: write_sample_unchecked
defs.value: pub unsafe fn write_sample_unchecked<S: Sample>(&mut Self, S)
defs.docs:
Like `write_sample()`, but does not perform a bounds check when writing
 to the internal buffer.

attributes.value: / Like `write_sample()`, but does not perform a bounds check when writing
/ to the internal buffer.
/ It is the responsibility of the programmer to ensure that no more
/ samples are written than allocated when the writer was created.
inline(always)

defs.name: flush
defs.docs: Flush the internal buffer to the underlying writer.

attributes.value: / Flush the internal buffer to the underlying writer.
/ # Panics
/ Panics if insufficient samples (less than specified when the writer was
/ constructed) have been written with `write_sample()`.

defs.name: Sample
defs.docs: A type that can be used to represent audio samples.

attributes.value: / A type that can be used to represent audio samples.
/ Via this trait, decoding can be generic over `i8`, `i16`, `i32` and `f32`.
/ All integer formats with bit depths up to 32 bits per sample can be decoded
/ into `i32`, but it takes up more memory. If you know beforehand that you
/ will be reading a file with 16 bits per sample, then decoding into an `i16`
/ will be sufficient.

defs.name: write
defs.value: pub fn write<W: io::Write>(Self, &mut W, u16) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Writes the audio sample to the WAVE data chunk.

attributes.value: / Writes the audio sample to the WAVE data chunk.

defs.name: read
defs.value: pub fn read<R: io::Read>(&mut R, SampleFormat, u16, u16) -> Result<Self>
defs.docs: Reads the audio sample from the WAVE data chunk.

attributes.value: / Reads the audio sample from the WAVE data chunk.

defs.name: as_i16
defs.docs: Cast the sample to a 16-bit sample.

attributes.value: / Cast the sample to a 16-bit sample.
/ This does not change the value of the sample, it only casts it. The
/ value is assumed to fit within the range. This is not verified,
/ truncation may occur.

defs.name: Float
defs.docs:
Wave files with the `WAVE_FORMAT_IEEE_FLOAT` format tag store samples as floating point
 values.

attributes.value: / Wave files with the `WAVE_FORMAT_IEEE_FLOAT` format tag store samples as floating point
/ values.
/ Values are normally in the range [-1.0, 1.0].

defs.name: Int
defs.docs: Wave files with the `WAVE_FORMAT_PCM` format tag store samples as integer values.

attributes.value: / Wave files with the `WAVE_FORMAT_PCM` format tag store samples as integer values.

defs.name: SampleFormat
defs.docs: Specifies whether a sample is stored as an "IEEE Float" or an integer.

attributes.value: / Specifies whether a sample is stored as an "IEEE Float" or an integer.

defs.name: WavSpec
defs.docs: Specifies properties of the audio data.

attributes.value: / Specifies properties of the audio data.

defs.name: channels
defs.docs: The number of channels.

attributes.value: / The number of channels.

defs.name: sample_rate
defs.docs: The number of samples per second.

attributes.value: / The number of samples per second.
/ A common value is 44100, this is 44.1 kHz which is used for CD audio.

defs.name: bits_per_sample
defs.docs: The number of bits per sample.

attributes.value: / The number of bits per sample.
/ A common value is 16 bits per sample, which is used for CD audio.

defs.name: sample_format
defs.docs: Whether the wav's samples are float or integer values.

attributes.value: / Whether the wav's samples are float or integer values.

defs.name: IoError
defs.docs: An IO error occured in the underlying reader or writer.

attributes.value: / An IO error occured in the underlying reader or writer.

defs.name: FormatError
defs.docs: Ill-formed WAVE data was encountered.

attributes.value: / Ill-formed WAVE data was encountered.

defs.name: TooWide
defs.docs: The sample has more bits than the destination type.

attributes.value: / The sample has more bits than the destination type.
/ When iterating using the `samples` iterator, this means that the
/ destination type (produced by the iterator) is not wide enough to hold
/ the sample. When writing, this means that the sample cannot be written,
/ because it requires more bits than the bits per sample specified.

defs.name: UnfinishedSample
defs.docs: The number of samples written is not a multiple of the number of channels.

attributes.value: / The number of samples written is not a multiple of the number of channels.

defs.name: Unsupported
defs.docs: The format is not supported.

attributes.value: / The format is not supported.

defs.name: InvalidSampleFormat
defs.docs: The sample format is different than the destination format.

attributes.value: / The sample format is different than the destination format.
/ When iterating using the `samples` iterator, this means the destination
/ type (produced by the iterator) has a different sample format than the
/ samples in the wav file.
/ For example, this will occur if the user attempts to produce `i32`
/ samples (which have a `SampleFormat::Int`) from a wav file that
/ contains floating point data (`SampleFormat::Float`).

defs.name: Error
defs.value:
pub enum Error {
    IoError(io::Error),
    FormatError(&'static str),
    TooWide,
    UnfinishedSample,
    Unsupported,
    InvalidSampleFormat,
}
defs.docs: The error type for operations on `WavReader` and `WavWriter`.

attributes.value: / The error type for operations on `WavReader` and `WavWriter`.

defs.name: Result
defs.docs: A type for results generated by Hound where the error type is hard-wired.

attributes.value: / A type for results generated by Hound where the error type is hard-wired.
